message_1: Suppose you want to test the effect of temperature and pressure on the yield of a chemical reaction, where temperature can be set to one of four levels and pressure can be set to one of three levels. Use an orthogonal array of size 12 to determine the combinations of temperature and pressure levels that should be tested.
message_2:
An orthogonal array is a systematic way of designing experiments to test multiple factors at different levels. In this case, we have two factors: temperature (with 4 levels) and pressure (with 3 levels). To create an orthogonal array of size 12, we can use the L12 array, which is suitable for testing two factors with different levels (4 and 3 in this case).

The L12 orthogonal array can be represented as follows:

| Experiment | Temperature | Pressure |
|------------|-------------|----------|
| 1          | 1           | 1        |
| 2          | 1           | 2        |
| 3          | 1           | 3        |
| 4          | 2           | 1        |
| 5          | 2           | 2        |
| 6          | 2           | 3        |
| 7          | 3           | 1        |
| 8          | 3           | 2        |
| 9          | 3           | 3        |
| 10         | 4           | 1        |
| 11         | 4           | 2        |
| 12         | 4           | 3        |

In this L12 orthogonal array, we have 12 experiments, each with a unique combination of temperature and pressure levels. This array ensures that each level of temperature is tested with each level of pressure, providing a balanced and efficient way to study the effects of both factors on the yield of the chemical reaction.
